Fundus and Retina are the two main components of the eye. The fundus is a layer of skin that covers the inner surface of the eye, providing vision and protecting it from damage caused by the outside world. It has no blood supply or nerve connections to the brain, making it an important part of the eye's overall health.

The retina, on the other hand, is a layer of light-sensitive cells located in front of the center of the eye. It provides visual information to the brain through its sensitivity to light, allowing us to see objects, colors, and patterns. Retinal diseases can cause changes in vision quality, such as blurriness, double vision, or loss of color contrast.

In summary, Fundus and Retina provide critical support for our eyes while also contributing to their overall well-being.
